phonegame
Class GameSound

java.lang.Object
  phonegame.GameSound

public final class GameSound
extends java.lang.Object

This class features a number of static methods that can be used to add sound to your game. Please notice that not all phones support the use of audio in Java.

Only MIDP 2.0 phones and phones that implement the MMAPI optional package (JSR 135) support the playback of audiofiles / tones. If you use this class on phones that do not meet these requirements you simply won't hear any sound.

Version:
2.0, October 11, 2005, 2.1, April 24, 2006, 3.0, November 17, 2006
Author:
Tim Prijn, Richard Kettelerij & Paul Bergervoet

Method Detail

isPlaying

public static final boolean isPlaying()
Checks if a soundfile/tone is currently being played.

Returns:
true if sound is being played, false otherwise

playSound

public static final void playSound(java.lang.String midiFile,
                                   boolean stopPrevious,
                                   boolean playIndefinitely)
                            throws GameException
Play the given MIDI soundfile.

Parameters:
midiFile - the file that needs to be played
stopPrevious - true, if you want the previous sound(s) to be stopped (this maximizes compatibility with older phones), false if not
playIndefinitely - true if the sound should play continuesly, false if not
Throws:
GameException - if the midifile is invalid or if the device can't handle it

playTone

public static final void playTone(int note,
                                  int duration,
                                  int volume)
                           throws GameException
Playback a tone as specified by a note and its duration. A note is given in the range of 0 to 127 inclusive. A list of MIDI note numbers can be found here .

Notice that this method may utilize CPU resources significantly on devices that don't have hardware support for tone generation.

Parameters:
note - defines the tone of the note
duration - the duration of the tone in milli-seconds (must be positive)
volume - audio volume range from 0 to 100. 100 represents the maximum volume at the current hardware level. Setting the volume to a value less than 0 will set the volume to 0. Setting the volume to greater than 100 will set the volume to 100.
Throws:
GameException - if note/duration is incorrent or if there's a device related problem

resumeBackgroundSound

public static final void resumeBackgroundSound()
Resume playing a background sound or music, that has been stopped temorarily.
Does nothing if there is no background sound or if it is already playing,

See Also:
stopBackgroundSound(boolean temporarily)

stopBackgroundSound

public static final void stopBackgroundSound(boolean temporarily)
Stop playing sounds, especially background music. You can specify if you want to resume the sound later on with resumeBackgroundSound(). (The GameEngine does this at an incoming call).
Does nothing if no background sound is playing.

Parameters:
temporarily - true if you want to resume the sound later on, false if you really stop it
See Also:
resumeBackgroundSound()
